title: Authors and Citation
text: Vembye M, Pustejovsky J (2022). POMADE: Power Meta-Analysis Dependent Effects. R package version 0.1.0, https://mikkelvembye.github.io/POMADE/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {POMADE: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects},   author = {Mikkel H. Vembye and James E. Pustejovsky},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://mikkelvembye.github.io/POMADE/}, }

what: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: POMADE package provides functions conducting power analysis tests based correlated-hierarchical effects (CHE; Pustejovsky & Tipton, 2021), multi-level meta-analysis (MLMA; Van den Noortgate et al., 2013), correlated-effects (CE; Hedges et al., 2010) models meta-analysis dependent effect sizes, possibility vary assumptions variance estimation estimation degrees freedom. approximations aim replace Hedges & Pigott’s (2001) previous power approximation based assumption independence effect sizes, shown work inadequately predict power models handle dependent effect sizes (Vembye, Pustejovsky, & Pigott, 2022). package also includes functions creating graphical displays power analysis results.

title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: can install development version GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("MikkelVembye/POMADE")

title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: approximate power test overall average effect size, based CHE-RVE model (Pustejovsky & Tipton, 2021). assume study sample sizes number reported effect sizes per study similar recent meta-analysis examining effects co-teaching academic achievement. results can displayed plot easily assess power across range plausible scenarios.
code: library(POMADE) library(dplyr)  # Find more information about this dataset by executing the following command below # ?VWB22_pilot coteach_dat <- VWB22_pilot #glimpse(coteach_dat)  dat_kjsigma2j <- select(coteach_dat, kj, sigma2j = vg_ms_mean)   power_CHE_RVE_empirical <-    power_MADE(     J = seq(40, 60, 5),     mu = 0.1,     tau = c(0.05, 0.1, 0.2),     omega = c(0.1, 0.2),     rho = c(0.2, 0.7),     alpha = 0.05,     sigma2_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$sigma2j,     n_ES_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$kj,     model = "CHE",  # Default     var_df = "RVE", # Default     iterations = 10, # default = 100 (recommended)     seed = 10052510   )   power_CHE_RVE_empirical %>%   select(J, tau, omega, rho, power, mcse) %>%   head(10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 6 #>        J   tau omega   rho power    mcse #>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1    40  0.05   0.1   0.2 0.858 0.0168  #>  2    45  0.05   0.1   0.2 0.890 0.0190  #>  3    50  0.05   0.1   0.2 0.929 0.0131  #>  4    55  0.05   0.1   0.2 0.955 0.00611 #>  5    60  0.05   0.1   0.2 0.967 0.00751 #>  6    40  0.1    0.1   0.2 0.744 0.0152  #>  7    45  0.1    0.1   0.2 0.793 0.0198  #>  8    50  0.1    0.1   0.2 0.840 0.0135  #>  9    55  0.1    0.1   0.2 0.880 0.00709 #> 10    60  0.1    0.1   0.2 0.903 0.00941 power_CHE_RVE_plot <-    plot_MADE(     power_CHE_RVE_empirical,     power_min = .8,     expected_studies = c(45, 55)   )  power_CHE_RVE_plot

title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: Another approach power analysis focuses determining minimum detectable effect size (MDES) preset levels significance power. can obtained using mdes_MADE(). MDES data can plotted across plausible scenarios.
code: mdes_CHE_RVE_empirical <-    mdes_MADE(     J = seq(60, 90, 10),     tau = c(0, 0.25),     omega = c(0, 0.1),     rho = c(0.2, 0.7),     target_power = .8,     alpha = 0.05,     sigma2_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$sigma2j,     n_ES_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$kj,     model = "CHE",  # Default     var_df = "RVE", # Default     iterations = 10, # Default = 100 (recommended)     seed = 10052510   )  mdes_CHE_RVE_empirical %>%   select(J, tau, omega, rho, target_power, MDES) %>%   head(10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 6 #>        J   tau omega   rho target_power   MDES #>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1    60  0      0     0.2          0.8 0.0484 #>  2    60  0      0     0.7          0.8 0.0594 #>  3    60  0      0.1   0.2          0.8 0.0658 #>  4    60  0      0.1   0.7          0.8 0.0786 #>  5    60  0.25   0     0.2          0.8 0.127  #>  6    60  0.25   0     0.7          0.8 0.139  #>  7    60  0.25   0.1   0.2          0.8 0.130  #>  8    60  0.25   0.1   0.7          0.8 0.142  #>  9    70  0      0     0.2          0.8 0.0424 #> 10    70  0      0     0.7          0.8 0.0525 MDES_CHE_RVE_plot <-    plot_MADE(     data = mdes_CHE_RVE_empirical,      es_min = 0.10,     expected_studies = c(70, 80),     numbers_ynudge = 0.159   )  MDES_CHE_RVE_plot

what: Finding the number of studies needed to obtain a certain amount of power
title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: power approximation formulas can, furthermore, used understand many studies needed find given effect size considered practical concern given amount power. can conducted via min_studies_MADE(). plotted via  Alternatively, reviewers can investigate number studies needed varies across various values effect size practical concern.
code: min_studies_example <-    min_studies_MADE(     mu = c(0.1, 0.15, 0.2),     tau = c(0.1, 0.2),     omega = c(0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3),     rho = c(0.2, 0.7),     target_power = .8,     alpha = 0.05,     sigma2_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$sigma2j,     n_ES_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$kj,     model = "CHE",  # Default     var_df = "RVE", # Default     iterations = 10, # Default = 100 (recommended)     seed = 10052510, )  min_studies_example %>%   select(mu, tau, omega, rho, target_power, studies_needed) %>%   head(10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 6 #>       mu   tau omega   rho target_power studies_needed #>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>          <dbl> #>  1   0.1   0.1   0     0.2          0.8             36 #>  2   0.1   0.1   0     0.7          0.8             46 #>  3   0.1   0.1   0.1   0.2          0.8             42 #>  4   0.1   0.1   0.1   0.7          0.8             54 #>  5   0.1   0.1   0.2   0.2          0.8             55 #>  6   0.1   0.1   0.2   0.7          0.8             73 #>  7   0.1   0.1   0.3   0.2          0.8             73 #>  8   0.1   0.1   0.3   0.7          0.8             96 #>  9   0.1   0.2   0     0.2          0.8             73 #> 10   0.1   0.2   0     0.7          0.8             90 min_studies_plot <-    min_studies_example %>%   filter(mu == 0.1) %>%   plot_MADE()  min_studies_plot min_studies_plot2 <-    plot_MADE(     min_studies_example   )  min_studies_plot2

title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: Traffic light plots add graphical representation likelihood different assumptions made meta-analyst. can specified plot_MADE(), . Assumptions specified upper left lower right facet grid plot.
code: plot_MADE(   power_CHE_RVE_empirical,   power_min = .8,   expected_studies = c(45, 55),   traffic_light_assumptions = c("unlikely", "likely", "expected", "expected", "likely") )

title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: core functions package allow parallel processing via future furrr packages.
code: library(future)  plan(sequential)  system.time(   res_seq <-      mdes_MADE(       J = seq(60, 90, 10),       tau = c(0, 0.25),       omega = c(0, 0.1),       rho = 0.7,       target_power = .8,       alpha = 0.05,       sigma2_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$sigma2j,       n_ES_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$kj,       iterations = 100,       seed = 10052510     ) ) #>    user  system elapsed  #>   40.45    0.33   41.15  plan(multisession, workers = 2)  system.time(   res_par <-      mdes_MADE(       J = seq(60, 90, 10),       tau = c(0, 0.25),       omega = c(0, 0.1),       rho = 0.7,       target_power = .8,       alpha = 0.05,       sigma2_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$sigma2j,       n_ES_dist = dat_kjsigma2j$kj,       iterations = 100,       seed = 10052510     ) ) #>    user  system elapsed  #>    0.08    0.01   24.46  identical(res_seq, res_par) #> [1] TRUE

title: Power for Meta-Analysis of Dependent Effects
text: Hedges, L. V., & Pigott T. D. (2001). power statistical tests meta-analysis. Psychological Methods, 6(3), 203-217. https://doi.org/10.1037/1082-989X.6.3.203 Hedges, L. V., Tipton, E., & Johnson, M. C. (2010). Robust variance estimation meta‐regression dependent effect size estimates. Research Synthesis Methods, 1(1), 39–65. https://doi.org/10.1002/jrsm.5 Pustejovsky, J. E., & Tipton E. (2021). Meta-analysis robust variance estimation: Expanding range working models. Prevention Science, 23(1), 425-438. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11121-021-01246-3 Van den Noortgate, W., López-López, J., Marín-Martínez, F., & Sánchez-Meca, J. (2013). Three-level meta-analysis dependent effect sizes. Behavior Research Methods, 45(2), 576–594. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13428-012-0261-6 Vembye, M. H., Pustejovsky, J. E., & Pigott, T. D. (2022). Power approximations overall average effects meta-analysis dependent effect sizes. Journal Educational Behavioral Statistics, 1–33. https://doi.org/10.3102/10769986221127379

title: Co-teaching Dataset — VWB22_pilot
text: Data meta-analysis effects collaborative models instruction student achievement Vembye, Weiss, Bhat (press/forthcoming).

title: Co-teaching Dataset — VWB22_pilot
code: VWB22_pilot

title: Co-teaching Dataset — VWB22_pilot
text: tibble 76 rows/studies 9 variables study_year Study author year publication studyid Unique study ID esid Unique effect size ID kj Number effect sizes per study N_meanj Average sample size study Nt_meanj Average sample size treatment group within study Nc_meanj Average sample size control group within study ESS_meanj Roughly approximated effective sample sizes vg_ms_mean Average cluster bias corrected sampling variance estimates

title: Co-teaching Dataset — VWB22_pilot
text: Find background material Vembye's OSF page, preprint https://osf.io/preprints/metaarxiv/mq5v7/.

title: Co-teaching Dataset — VWB22_pilot
text: Vembye, M. H., Weiss, F., & Bhat, B. H. (press/forthcoming). Effects Co-Teaching Related Collaborative Models Instruction Student Achievement: Systematic Review Meta-Analysis. Review Educational Research. Access background material https://osf.io/fby7w/.

title: Cluster Bias Correction — cluster_bias_adjustment
text: Function conduct cluster bias correction sampling variance estimates obtained cluster-randomized studies reported variance account clustering.

title: Cluster Bias Correction — cluster_bias_adjustment
code: cluster_bias_adjustment(sigma2js, cluster_size = 22, icc = 0.2)

title: Cluster Bias Correction — cluster_bias_adjustment
text: sigma2js vector sampling variance estimates account clustering. cluster_size numerical value average cluster size. icc Assumed intra-class correlation (proportion total variance cluster level).

title: Cluster Bias Correction — cluster_bias_adjustment
text: Returns vector cluster bias adjusted variance estimates

title: Cluster Bias Correction — cluster_bias_adjustment
code: cbc_var <- cluster_bias_adjustment(   sigma2js = c(0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.1),   cluster_size = 15,   icc = 0.15 )  cbc_var #> [1] 0.124 0.186 0.248 0.310

title: Approximate Effective Sample Sizes — effective_sample_sizes
text: Approximate Effective Sample Sizes

title: Approximate Effective Sample Sizes — effective_sample_sizes
code: effective_sample_sizes(   sample_sizes_raw = NULL,   Nt_raw = NULL,   Nc_raw = NULL,   cluster_size = 22,   icc = 0.22 )

title: Approximate Effective Sample Sizes — effective_sample_sizes
text: sample_sizes_raw Vector raw total study sample size(s). Nt_raw Vector raw treatment group sample size(s). Nc_raw Vector raw control group sample size(s). cluster_size Average cluster size (Default = 22, common class size education research studies). icc Assumed intra-class correlation (Default = 0.22, average ICC value Hedges & Hedberg (2007) unconditional models)

title: Approximate Effective Sample Sizes — effective_sample_sizes
text: vector effective sample sizes, adjusted cluster-dependence.

title: Approximate Effective Sample Sizes — effective_sample_sizes
text: N_j/DE

title: Approximate Effective Sample Sizes — effective_sample_sizes

what:
Minimum Detectable Effect Size (MDES) for Meta-Analysis With Dependent
Effect Sizes — mdes_MADE
title:
Minimum Detectable Effect Size (MDES) for Meta-Analysis With Dependent
Effect Sizes — mdes_MADE
text: Compute minimum detectable effect size meta-analysis dependent effect size estimates, given specified number studies, power level, estimation method, assumptions distribution studies.

title:
Minimum Detectable Effect Size (MDES) for Meta-Analysis With Dependent
Effect Sizes — mdes_MADE
code: mdes_MADE(   J,   tau,   omega,   rho,   alpha = 0.05,   target_power = 0.8,   d = 0,   model = "CHE",   var_df = "RVE",   sigma2_dist = NULL,   n_ES_dist = NULL,   iterations = 100,   seed = NULL,   warning = TRUE,   upper = 2,   show_lower = FALSE )

title:
Minimum Detectable Effect Size (MDES) for Meta-Analysis With Dependent
Effect Sizes — mdes_MADE
text: J Number studies. Can one value vector multiple values. tau -study SD. Can one value vector multiple values. omega Within-study SD. Can one value vector multiple values. rho Correlation coefficient effect size estimates study. Can one value vector multiple values. alpha Level statistical significance. Can one value vector multiple values. Default 0.05. target_power Numerical value specifying target power level. Can one value vector multiple values. d Contrast value. Can one value vector multiple values. Default 0. model Assumed working model dependent effect sizes, either "CHE" correlated--hierarchical effects model, "CE" correlated effects model, "MLMA" multi-level meta-analysis model. Default "CHE". Can one value vector multiple values. var_df Indicates technique used obtain sampling variance average effect size estimate degrees freedom, either "Model" model-based variance estimator degrees freedom J - 1, "Satt" model-based variance estimator Satterthwaite degrees freedom, "RVE" robust variance estimator Satterthwaite degrees freedom. Default "RVE". Can one value vector multiple values. sigma2_dist Distribution sampling variance estimates study. Can either single value, vector plausible values, function generates random values. n_ES_dist Distribution number effect sizes per study. Can either single value, vector plausible values, function generates random values. iterations Number iterations per condition (default 100). seed Numerical value seed ensure reproducibility iterated power approximations. warning Logical indicating whether return warning either sigma2_dist n_ES_dist based balanced assumptions. upper Numerical value containing upper bound interval searched MDES. show_lower Logical value indicating whether report lower bound interval searched MDES. Default FALSE.

title:
Minimum Detectable Effect Size (MDES) for Meta-Analysis With Dependent
Effect Sizes — mdes_MADE
text: Returns tibble information expectation number studies, -study within-study variance components, sample correlation, contrast effect, level statistical significance, target power value(s), minimum detectable effect size, number iterations, model handle dependent effect sizes, methods used obtain sampling variance estimates well number effect sizes per study.

title:
Minimum Detectable Effect Size (MDES) for Meta-Analysis With Dependent
Effect Sizes — mdes_MADE
code: mdes_MADE(   J = 30,   tau = 0.05,   omega = 0.02,   rho = 0.2,   model = "CHE",   var_df = "RVE",   sigma2_dist = 4 / 100,   n_ES_dist = 6,   seed = 10052510 ) #> Warning: Notice: It is generally recommended not to draw on balanced assumptions regarding the study precision (sigma2js) or the number of effect sizes per study (kjs). See Figures 2A and 2B in Vembye, Pustejovsky, and Pigott (2022). #> # A tibble: 1 × 12 #>       J   tau omega   rho     d alpha target_power   MDES iterat…¹ model samp_…² #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl> <chr> <chr>   #> 1    30  0.05  0.02   0.2     0  0.05          0.8 0.0667      100 CHE-… balanc… #> # … with 1 more variable: samp_method_kj <chr>, and abbreviated variable names #> #   ¹​iterations, ²​samp_method_sigma2

title:
Finding the Number of Studies Needed to Obtain a Certain Amount of
Power — min_studies_MADE
text: Compute minimum number studies needed obtain specified power level meta-analysis dependent effect size estimates, given effect size practical concern, estimation method, assumptions distribution studies.

title:
Finding the Number of Studies Needed to Obtain a Certain Amount of
Power — min_studies_MADE
code: min_studies_MADE(   mu,   tau,   omega,   rho,   alpha = 0.05,   target_power = 0.8,   d = 0,   model = "CHE",   var_df = "RVE",   sigma2_dist = NULL,   n_ES_dist = NULL,   iterations = 100,   seed = NULL,   warning = TRUE,   upper = 100,   show_lower = FALSE )

title:
Finding the Number of Studies Needed to Obtain a Certain Amount of
Power — min_studies_MADE
text: mu Effect size practical concern. Can one value vector multiple values. tau -study SD. Can one value vector multiple values. omega Within-study SD. Can one value vector multiple values. rho Correlation coefficient effect size estimates study. Can one value vector multiple values. alpha Level statistical significance. Can one value vector multiple values. Default 0.05. target_power Numerical value specifying target power level. Can one value vector multiple values. d Contrast value. Can one value vector multiple values. Default 0. model Assumed working model dependent effect sizes, either "CHE" correlated--hierarchical effects model, "CE" correlated effects model, "MLMA" multi-level meta-analysis model. Default "CHE". Can one value vector multiple values. var_df Indicates technique used obtain sampling variance average effect size estimate degrees freedom, either "Model" model-based variance estimator degrees freedom J - 1, "Satt" model-based variance estimator Satterthwaite degrees freedom, "RVE" robust variance estimator Satterthwaite degrees freedom. Default "RVE". Can one value vector multiple values. sigma2_dist Distribution sampling variance estimates study. Can either single value, vector plausible values, function generates random values. n_ES_dist Distribution number effect sizes per study. Can either single value, vector plausible values, function generates random values. iterations Number iterations per condition (default 100). seed Numerical value seed ensure reproducibility iterated power approximations. warning Logical indicating whether return warning either sigma2_dist n_ES_dist based balanced assumptions. upper Numerical value containing upper bound interval searched minimum number studies. show_lower Logical value indicating whether report lower bound interval searched minimum number studies. Default FALSE.

title:
Finding the Number of Studies Needed to Obtain a Certain Amount of
Power — min_studies_MADE
text: Returns tibble information expectation effect size practical concern, -study within-study variance components, sample correlation, contrast effect, level statistical significance, target power value(s), number studies needed, number iterations, model handle dependent effect sizes, methods used obtain sampling variance estimates well number effect sizes per study.

title:
Finding the Number of Studies Needed to Obtain a Certain Amount of
Power — min_studies_MADE
code: min_studies_MADE(   mu = 0.3,   tau = 0.05,   omega = 0.01,   rho = 0.2,   target_power = .7,   alpha = 0.05,   model = "CE",   var_df = "RVE",   sigma2_dist = 4 / 200,   n_ES_dist = 5.5,   seed = 10052510 ) #> Warning: Notice: It is generally recommended not to draw on balanced assumptions regarding the study precision (sigma2js) or the number of effect sizes per study (kjs). See Figures 2A and 2B in Vembye, Pustejovsky, and Pigott (2022). #> # A tibble: 1 × 12 #>      mu   tau omega   rho     d alpha target_power studi…¹ itera…² model samp_…³ #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <chr> <chr>   #> 1   0.3  0.05  0.01   0.2     0  0.05          0.7       5     100 CE-R… balanc… #> # … with 1 more variable: samp_method_kj <chr>, and abbreviated variable names #> #   ¹​studies_needed, ²​iterations, ³​samp_method_sigma2

what: Generic plot function for 'MADE' objects — plot_MADE
title: Generic plot function for 'MADE' objects — plot_MADE
text: Create faceted plot displaying results set power analyses. generic function make facet_grid plots, specific methods defined power_MADE, mdes_MADE, min_studies_MADE objects.

title: Generic plot function for 'MADE' objects — plot_MADE
code: plot_MADE(   data,   v_lines,   legend_position,   color,   numbers,   number_size,   numbers_ynudge,   caption,   x_lab,   x_breaks,   x_limits,   y_breaks,   y_limits,   y_expand = NULL,   warning,   traffic_light_assumptions,   ... )

title: Generic plot function for 'MADE' objects — plot_MADE
text: data Data/object plot made. v_lines Integer vector specify vertical line(s) within plot. Default NULL. legend_position Character string specify position legend. Default "bottom". color Logical indicating whether use color plot(s). Default TRUE. numbers Logical indicating whether number plots. Default TRUE. number_size Integer value specifying size (optional) plot numbers. Default 2.5. numbers_ynudge Integer value vertical nudge (optional) plot numbers. caption Logical indicating whether include caption detailed information regarding analysis. Default TRUE. x_lab Title x-axis. NULL (default), x_lab specified automatically. x_breaks Optional vector specify breaks x-axis. Default NULL. x_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits x-axis. Default NULL, allows limits determined automatically data. y_breaks Optional vector specify breaks y-axis. y_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits y-axis. y_expand Optional vector expand limits y-axis. Default NULL. warning Logical indicating whether warnings returned multiple models appear data. Default TRUE. traffic_light_assumptions Optional logical specify coloring strips facet grids emphasize assumptions likelihood given analytical scenario. See Vembye, Pustejovsky, & Pigott (preparation) details. ... Additional arguments available classes objects.

title: Generic plot function for 'MADE' objects — plot_MADE
text: ggplot object

title: Generic plot function for 'MADE' objects — plot_MADE
text: Vembye, M. H., Pustejovsky, J. E., & Pigott, T. D. (preparation). Conducting power analysis meta-analysis dependent effect sizes: Common guidelines introduction POMADE R package.

title: Generic plot function for 'MADE' objects — plot_MADE
code: power_dat <-   power_MADE(     J = c(50, 56),     mu = 0.15,     tau = 0.1,     omega = 0.05,     rho = 0,     sigma2_dist = 4 / 200,     n_ES_dist = 6   ) #> Warning: Notice: It is generally recommended not to draw on balanced assumptions regarding the study precision (sigma2js) or the number of effect sizes per study (kjs). See Figures 2A and 2B in Vembye, Pustejovsky, and Pigott (2022).  power_example <-   plot_MADE(    data = power_dat,    power_min = 0.8,    expected_studies = c(52, 54),    warning = FALSE,    caption = TRUE,    color = TRUE,    model_comparison = FALSE,    numbers = FALSE    )  power_example

title: Plot function for a 'mdes' object — plot_MADE.mdes
code: # S3 method for mdes plot_MADE(   data,   v_lines = NULL,   legend_position = "bottom",   color = TRUE,   numbers = TRUE,   number_size = 2.5,   numbers_ynudge = NULL,   caption = TRUE,   x_lab = NULL,   x_breaks = NULL,   x_limits = NULL,   y_breaks = ggplot2::waiver(),   y_limits = NULL,   y_expand = NULL,   warning = TRUE,   traffic_light_assumptions = NULL,   es_min = NULL,   expected_studies = NULL,   ... )

title: Plot function for a 'mdes' object — plot_MADE.mdes
text: data Data/object plot made. v_lines Integer vector specify vertical line(s) within plot. Default NULL. legend_position Character string specify position legend. Default "bottom". color Logical indicating whether use color plot(s). Default TRUE. numbers Logical indicating whether number plots. Default TRUE. number_size Integer value specifying size (optional) plot numbers. Default 2.5. numbers_ynudge Integer value vertical nudge (optional) plot numbers. caption Logical indicating whether include caption detailed information regarding analysis. Default TRUE. x_lab Title x-axis. NULL (default), x_lab specified automatically. x_breaks Optional vector specify breaks x-axis. Default NULL. x_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits x-axis. Default NULL, allows limits determined automatically data. y_breaks Optional vector specify breaks y-axis. y_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits y-axis. y_expand Optional vector expand limits y-axis. Default NULL. warning Logical indicating whether warnings returned multiple models appear data. Default TRUE. traffic_light_assumptions Optional logical specify coloring strips facet grids emphasize assumptions likelihood given analytical scenario. See Vembye, Pustejovsky, & Pigott (preparation) details. es_min Optional integer vector specify horizontal line interval, indicating benchmark value values minimum effect size practical concern (default NULL). expected_studies Optional vector length 2 specifying range number studies one expects include meta-analysis. specified, interval shaded across facet_grip plots (default NULL). ... Additional arguments available classes objects.

title: Plot function for a 'mdes' object — plot_MADE.mdes
text: ggplot plot showing minimum detectable effect size across expected number studies, faceted -study within-study SDs, different colors, lines, shapes corresponding different values assumed sample correlation.

title: Plot function for a 'mdes' object — plot_MADE.mdes
text: general, can rather difficult guess/approximate true model parameters sample characteristics priori. Calculating minimum detectable effect size just single set assumptions can easily misleading even true model data structure slightly diverge yielded data model assumptions. maximize informativeness analysis, Vembye, Pustejovsky, & Pigott (preparation) suggest accommodating uncertainty power approximations reporting plotting minimum detectable effect size estimates across range possible scenarios, can done using plot_MADE.mdes.

title: Plot function for a 'mdes' object — plot_MADE.mdes
text: Vembye, M. H., Pustejovsky, J. E., & Pigott, T. D. (preparation). Conducting power analysis meta-analysis dependent effect sizes: Common guidelines introduction POMADE R package.

title: Plot function for a 'mdes' object — plot_MADE.mdes
code: mdes_MADE(   J = c(25, 35),   tau = 0.05,   omega = 0,   rho = 0,   target_power = .6,   alpha = 0.1,   sigma2_dist = 4 / 200,   n_ES_dist = 8,   seed = 10052510 ) |>   plot_MADE(expected_studies = c(28, 32), numbers = FALSE) #> Warning: Notice: It is generally recommended not to draw on balanced assumptions regarding the study precision (sigma2js) or the number of effect sizes per study (kjs). See Figures 2A and 2B in Vembye, Pustejovsky, and Pigott (2022).

what: Plot function for a 'min_studies' object — plot_MADE.min_studies

code: # S3 method for min_studies plot_MADE(   data,   v_lines = NULL,   legend_position = "bottom",   color = TRUE,   numbers = TRUE,   number_size = 2.5,   numbers_ynudge = NULL,   caption = TRUE,   x_lab = NULL,   x_breaks = NULL,   x_limits = NULL,   y_breaks = ggplot2::waiver(),   y_limits = NULL,   y_expand = NULL,   warning = TRUE,   traffic_light_assumptions = NULL,   v_shade = NULL,   h_lines = NULL,   ... )

title: Plot function for a 'min_studies' object — plot_MADE.min_studies
text: data Data/object plot made. v_lines Integer vector specify vertical line(s) within plot. Default NULL. legend_position Character string specify position legend. Default "bottom". color Logical indicating whether use color plot(s). Default TRUE. numbers Logical indicating whether number plots. Default TRUE. number_size Integer value specifying size (optional) plot numbers. Default 2.5. numbers_ynudge Integer value vertical nudge (optional) plot numbers. caption Logical indicating whether include caption detailed information regarding analysis. Default TRUE. x_lab Title x-axis. NULL (default), x_lab specified automatically. x_breaks Optional vector specify breaks x-axis. Default NULL. x_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits x-axis. Default NULL, allows limits determined automatically data. y_breaks Optional vector specify breaks y-axis. y_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits y-axis. y_expand Optional vector expand limits y-axis. Default NULL. warning Logical indicating whether warnings returned multiple models appear data. Default TRUE. traffic_light_assumptions Optional logical specify coloring strips facet grids emphasize assumptions likelihood given analytical scenario. See Vembye, Pustejovsky, & Pigott (preparation) details. v_shade Optional vector length 2 specifying range x-axis interval shaded plot. h_lines Optional integer vector specifying horizontal lines plot. ... Additional arguments available classes objects.

code: # S3 method for power plot_MADE(   data,   v_lines = NULL,   legend_position = "bottom",   color = TRUE,   numbers = TRUE,   number_size = 2.5,   numbers_ynudge = 0,   caption = TRUE,   x_lab = NULL,   x_breaks = NULL,   x_limits = NULL,   y_breaks = seq(0, 1, 0.2),   y_limits = c(0, 1),   y_expand = NULL,   warning = TRUE,   traffic_light_assumptions = NULL,   power_min = NULL,   expected_studies = NULL,   model_comparison = FALSE,   ... )

title: Plot function for a 'power' object — plot_MADE.power
text: data Data/object plot made. v_lines Integer vector specify vertical line(s) within plot. Default NULL. legend_position Character string specify position legend. Default "bottom". color Logical indicating whether use color plot(s). Default TRUE. numbers Logical indicating whether number plots. Default TRUE. number_size Integer value specifying size (optional) plot numbers. Default 2.5. numbers_ynudge Integer value vertical nudge (optional) plot numbers. caption Logical indicating whether include caption detailed information regarding analysis. Default TRUE. x_lab Title x-axis. NULL (default), x_lab specified automatically. x_breaks Optional vector specify breaks x-axis. Default NULL. x_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits x-axis. Default NULL, allows limits determined automatically data. y_breaks Optional vector specify breaks y-axis. y_limits Optional vector length 2 specify limits y-axis. y_expand Optional vector expand limits y-axis. Default NULL. warning Logical indicating whether warnings returned multiple models appear data. Default TRUE. traffic_light_assumptions Optional logical specify coloring strips facet grids emphasize assumptions likelihood given analytical scenario. See Vembye, Pustejovsky, & Pigott (preparation) details. power_min Either integer specify horizontal line length-2 vector specify interval, indicating benchmark level power (default NULL). expected_studies Optional vector length 2 specifying range number studies one expects include meta-analysis. specified, interval shaded across facet_grip plots (default NULL). model_comparison Logical indicating whether power estimates plotted across different working models dependent effect size estimates (default FALSE) instead across values sampling correlation. ... Additional arguments available classes objects.

title: Plot function for a 'power' object — plot_MADE.power
code: power_dat <-   power_MADE(     J = c(50, 56),     mu = 0.15,     tau = 0.1,     omega = 0.05,     rho = 0,     sigma2_dist = 4 / 200,     n_ES_dist = 6   ) #> Warning: Notice: It is generally recommended not to draw on balanced assumptions regarding the study precision (sigma2js) or the number of effect sizes per study (kjs). See Figures 2A and 2B in Vembye, Pustejovsky, and Pigott (2022).  power_example <-   plot_MADE(    data = power_dat,    power_min = 0.8,    expected_studies = c(52, 54),    warning = FALSE,    caption = TRUE,    color = TRUE,    model_comparison = FALSE,    numbers = FALSE    )  power_example

what: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
title: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
text: Compute power test overall average effect size meta-analysis dependent effect size estimates, given specified number studies, effect size practical concern, estimation method, assumptions distribution studies.

title: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
code: power_MADE(   J,   mu,   tau,   omega,   rho,   alpha = 0.05,   d = 0,   model = "CHE",   var_df = "RVE",   sigma2_dist = NULL,   n_ES_dist = NULL,   iterations = 100,   seed = NULL,   warning = TRUE,   average_power = TRUE )

title: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
text: J Number studies. Can one value vector multiple values. mu Effect size practical concern. Can one value vector multiple values. tau -study SD. Can one value vector multiple values. omega Within-study SD. Can one value vector multiple values. rho Correlation coefficient effect size estimates study. Can one value vector multiple values. alpha Level statistical significance. Can one value vector multiple values. Default 0.05. d Contrast value. Can one value vector multiple values. Default 0. model Assumed working model dependent effect sizes, either "CHE" correlated--hierarchical effects model, "CE" correlated effects model, "MLMA" multi-level meta-analysis model. Default "CHE". Can one value vector multiple values. var_df Indicates technique used obtain sampling variance average effect size estimate degrees freedom, either "Model" model-based variance estimator degrees freedom J - 1, "Satt" model-based variance estimator Satterthwaite degrees freedom, "RVE" robust variance estimator Satterthwaite degrees freedom. Default "RVE". Can one value vector multiple values. sigma2_dist Distribution sampling variance estimates study. Can either single value, vector plausible values, function generates random values. n_ES_dist Distribution number effect sizes per study. Can either single value, vector plausible values, function generates random values. iterations Number iterations per condition (default 100). seed Numerical value seed ensure reproducibility iterated power approximations. warning Logical indicating whether return warning either sigma2_dist n_ES_dist based balanced assumptions. average_power Logical indicating whether calculate average power across iterations condition.

title: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
text: Returns tibble information expectation number studies, effect size practical concern, -study within-study variance components, sample correlation, contrast effect, level statistical significance, sampling variance overall average effect size practical concern, degrees freedom, power, mcse, number iterations, model handle dependent effect sizes, methods used obtain sampling variance estimates well number effect sizes per study.

title: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
text: Find background material behind power approximations Vembye, Pustejovsky, & Pigott (2022), including arguments suggested neither conduct power analysis based balanced assumptions number effects per study study variance use original power approximation assuming independence among effect sizes (Hedges & Pigott, 2001).

title: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
text: Vembye, M. H., Pustejovsky, J. E., & Pigott, T. D. (2022). Power approximations overall average effects meta-analysis dependent effect sizes. Journal Educational Behavioral Statistics, 1–33. doi:10.3102/10769986221127379 Hedges, L. V., & Pigott, T. D. (2001). power statistical tests meta-analysis. Psychological Methods, 6(3), 203–217. doi:10.1037/1082-989X.6.3.203

title: Power Approximation for Overall Average Effects in  Meta-Analysis With Dependent Effect Sizes — power_MADE
